newsitem.title: USA: Dow could rally on weak March jobs report - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Dow could rally on weak March jobs report - analysts.

text.p: The besieged Dow Jones industrial average could rally on Friday if a key report on March employment shows no signs of a tightening labor market.
The report is expected to show the U.S. economy created 196,000 new nonfarm jobs in March, compared with 339,000 in February, according to a Reuters survey.

The data will be dissected for any signs of mounting labor-cost pressures, which could increase the risk of the Federal Reserve moving to raise interest rates at its May 20 policy-making meeting or its next session in June.

"If the numbers are weak and shift the entrenched thought process that there will be a hike at the May meeting ... we could have a great rebound day. We could have a 100-point-up day," said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear Stearns.
The report also includes average hourly earnings, the unemployment rate and the length of the average work week.
"Wages are what the Fed is paying attention to, so the market is focused on that," said Jennifer Moran, associate to the chief economist at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette.
U.S. economists polled by Reuters forecast average hourly wages climbed 0.4 percent in March compared with a 0.2 percent rise in February.
Heightened concern about rising rates have helped push the Dow industrials down 608 points, or 8.5 percent, from its March 11 high of 7085. The index closed Thursday at 6477.
The Fed moved to raise interest rates for the first time in two years on March 25, when it lifted the key federal funds short-term rate by 0.25 percentage point.
